subsections.content: The structure was constructed within the sacred precinct of the god. What should also be noted here is that the rites of Dionysus so closely resembled those of the Egyptian god Osiris that Herodotus thought it impossible for the Greek rites to have risen independently of the Egyptian ones. Therefore, he supposed that the Greeks must have borrowed their rites from the Egyptians and, with slight alterations, passed them on as their own. So, incidentally, did Plutarch, who insisted upon the detailed resemblances between the rites of Osiris and those of Dionysus, which, if nothing else, indicates that comparative mythology is not merely a modern tool that some of its critics maintain. In this instance, as in many others, however, no borrowing need be called for. What is at bottom here is that whatever Dionysus originally stood for was the very same thing that the Egyptian Osiris had originally represented. Put simply, Osiris and Dionysus were representations of the same original phenomenon; they were, in essence, one and the same god under different national guises. Others, of course, have maintained that the similarity of Greek rituals to those of the Egyptians stems from the ignorance of the Greeks regarding Egyptian practices. For instance, Gwyn Griffiths tried to convince his readers that Greek observers were “not usually in a position” to understand Egyptian religion, particularly because of their ignorance of the Egyptian language. According to Griffiths, Greek theological explanations of Egyptian religious particulars and mythological equations were based on misunderstandings regarding Dionysus.

bibliography: W. Oates & E. O’Neil, The Complete Greek Drama (1938), p. xxiii.
J. G. Frazer, The Golden Bough (London, 1974, abridged edition), p. 507.
G. J. Griffiths, “Interpretatio Graeca,” in W. Helck & E. Otto, Lexikon der Agyptologie, Vol. III (1980).

subsections.content: The performance of Oedipus Rex in the theater of Dionysus on the south slope of the Acropolis of Athens was significant. Actors wore masks, each playing more than one role.
Note the altar of Dionysus at the center of the orchestra. (Illustration by John Green.)

Actors performing in a Roman Theater. Although it has been stated that Roman drama was a secular diversion with its roots in sacred Etruscan funeral rites, it was actually nothing more than a Greek derivative of Hellenic repertory. (Illustration by John Green.)

The misunderstandings of Egyptian phenomena, alongside modifications introduced in what observers perceived as Greek parallels, have often contributed to the misunderstandings of their origins. But, as Martin Bernal pointed out, these assertions concerning the Afroasiatic roots of Classical Greek culture are worth discussing. Despite critique from mainstream scholars, Bernal argued convincingly that many ancient Egyptian cultural aspects are often oversimplified, ignoring the depth of understanding of figures like Eudoxos, who lived closely with the priests and exhibited great respect for Egyptian culture. Notably, the term tragedy in Greek, tragodia, means “goat song,” derived from tragos, the sacred animal of Dionysus. This etymology suggests a clear connection to the reverence of Dionysus, as the goat song itself was sung in honor of the god, depicting his birth and violent end. The tragic connotation of “goat song” became understood as a synonym for misfortune.

bibliography: M. Bernal, Black Athena (New Brunswick, 1988), p. 118.
R. M. Dorson, “The Debate Over the Trustworthiness of Oral Traditional History,” cited by D. B. Vitaliano, Legends of the Earth (Bloomington, 1973), p. 4.

subsections.content: The accuracy with which the people of sub-Saharan Africa managed to preserve their history without a written language up until the colonial period is remarkable. When history is transmitted through a succession of professional bards with highly trained memories, it is likely to remain accurate even when put into writing centuries later. Alfred de Grazia noted that an exact rendition of a large body of verse and prose can be transmitted over generations. This technique resembles how nursery rhymes learned by rote can be recalled with precision years later. Parry suggested that Homeric hexameters were shaped by earlier oral traditions and likely aided the preservation of the epics through formulas shaped to fit particular line structures. This indicates that the oral tradition played a crucial role in the transmission of cultural narratives, with evidence of significant historical accuracy.

bibliography: C. Sagan & I. S. Shklovskii, Intelligent Life in the Universe (N.Y., 1966), p. 464.
P. Hallberg, The Icelandic Saga (Nebraska, 1962), p. 52.
A. de Grazia, God’s Fire (Princeton, 1983), p. 285.

subsections.content: Imagine a Scandinavian skald or bard reciting a saga from memory to a chieftain and his tribe during a gathering.

In recent years, Hildegard Wiencke-Lotz conducted an experiment traveling through Europe to track various versions of the Gudrun Epic. This epic, previously thought of as a fairy tale in three parts, was demonstrated to have a sound historical basis, with all specific places mentioned geographically accurate. Wiencke-Lotz visited numerous locations mentioned in the tales and traced the specific period of Gudrun’s life in relation to Roman history. This study revealed remarkable continuity in the narrative, even after a significant passage of time, highlighting the oral tradition's role in sustaining historical and geographical accuracy.

bibliography: D. Griffard, from the “Introductory Notes” to H. Wiencke-Lotz, “Folklore: Its Stability and Self-correcting Power,” HORUS II:2 (Summer 1986), p. 29.

subsections.content: Wiencke-Lotz's study encompassed regions such as Austria, Greece, Asia Minor, Poland, Russia, Sweden, Denmark, England, Germany, France, Spain, and even Morocco and Tunisia. She met with folklore-telling communities still existing in these countries, and their rendition of Gudrun songs and stories proved to be “absolutely trustworthy” compared to the written epic from 1233. This finding emphasizes the importance of oral tradition, where even minor deviations were corrected by the listeners, reinforcing community memory and fidelity to the narrative.

The invention of writing revolutionized the ancient world, offering numerous advantages. However, it also posed a disadvantage, as noted in the allegorical story of Thamus, the mythological king of Egypt, who reproached Thoth, the god of letters. He argued that the invention of writing could lead to forgetfulness in students, as it discourages the practice of memory. Thus, while the Egyptians had access to written texts, their understanding of the nuances of these words was often limited. Their oral traditions, recited from memory, retained a direct connection to the experiences of their ancestors.

bibliography: Plato, Phaedrus, as translated by H. N. Fowler, 274-275.
